questions.text: Paradoxical undressing is seen in :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypothermia

 

Explanation:

Hypothermia occurs when the body's core temperature falls below 36°C (96.8°F), leading to paradoxical undressing. This occurs due to disorientation and mental confusion as the body struggles to regulate temperature, causing the victim to undress, which paradoxically increases heat loss. This behavior can be mistaken for evidence of sexual assault or homicide.

 

Hypothermia

Definition

Core temperature below 36°C (96.8°F)

Signs
  • Disorientation
  • Dulling of consciousness
  • Loss of reflex
  • Fall in respiration, heart rate, and blood pressure
  • Red patches and pallor of the skin
  • Edema of the face
  • Stiffness of neck muscles

Autopsy findings
  • Patches of pink to brownish-pink discoloration
  • Postmortem staining: Pink/bright red
  • Cyanosis or pallor in extremities ("white deaths")
  • Edema of feet and blistering of skin
  • Stomach: Wischnewsky spots-brownish black colored gastric mucosal ulcers
  • Viscera-congested, hemorrhagic

Phenomena seen in hypothermia victims

  • Paradoxical undressing- found undressed due to disorientation which increases heat loss (mistaken for evidence of sexual assault or homicide)
  • ‘Hide and die' syndrome- found in unusual locations resembling an attempt to "hide" or create a protective environment due to mental confusion and a possible hibernation reflex (confused with signs of homicide or robbery)
  • Chilblain (Erythema Pernio)- red, itching skin lesions typically found on extremities due to cold exposure, often accompanied by edema and blistering.

 

Heart stress (Option A) typically refers to conditions that put pressure on the heart, such as heart attacks or heart failure. Paradoxical undressing is not associated with heart stress. It occurs due to hypothermia, where the body loses its ability to regulate temperature properly.

 

Voyeurism (Option B) is a psychological condition where individuals gain sexual pleasure from watching others without their knowledge. It is unrelated to paradoxical undressing, which is a phenomenon occurring due to hypothermia and confusion.


LSD overdose (Option D) can cause severe confusion, hallucinations, and altered perceptions, but it does not typically lead to paradoxical undressing. Hypothermia, not LSD overdose, is the primary cause of this phenomenon.

questions.text: During autopsy, a body shows curved scratch marks below the right angle of the mandible, three grouped bruises on the left side of the neck below the thyroid cartilage, and additional bruises over the head, posterior shoulder, backside of the trunk, and hip crests. Fracture of the superior horn of the thyroid cartilage present. What is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Throttling

Explanation:

  • Throttling refers to manual strangulation using the hands.

  • The described autopsy findings — curved scratch marks from fingernails, localized grouped bruises from finger pressure, and fracture of the superior horn of the thyroid cartilage — are classic for forceful compression of the neck by human hands.

  • Associated bruises on other body parts often indicate a struggle.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Garroting uses a tightened ligature, producing a horizontal mark.

Option C - Mugging is an assault type, not a pathological cause.

Option D - Ligature strangulation causes patterned marks from the cord, absent here.

questions.text: During an explosion, a patient sustains a crushed lower limb injury by collapse of a building. What type of blast injury does this represent?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Quaternary

Explanation:

  • Quaternary blast injuries include building collapse causing crush injuries.

Primary blast injury (Option A)

  • Air-wave/ blast wave/ shock wave - Air compression
  • Barotrauma damages hollow organs
    • Ear
      • Tympanic membrane- M/c, Ossicles, Bleeding, perforation
    • Lungs
      • Most fatal injury
      • Alveoli, capillaries injured (blast lung)
    • GIT
      • Vomiting, Perforation, Hematemesis, Melena

Secondary blast injury (Option B)

  • Flying missiles/ projectiles/ objects - Hitting body
    • Bruises
    • Abrasions
    • Punctate laceration

Tertiary blast injury (Option C)

  • Lifted and thrown around
    • Hits ground
    • Skeletal fractures/ displacements

Quaternary blast injury

  • Miscellaneous
    • Building collapse: Traumatic Asphyxia
    • Burn, Flame injuries

Quinary Blast Injuries

  • Environmental contaminants
  • Chemicals (Chloride, Savin)
  • Radiations (nuclear bomb)
  • Virus and bacteria.

questions.text: The triad of abrasions, contusions, and lacerations is most diagnostic of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) ﻿﻿﻿Bomb blast injury

Explanation:

  • Marshall's triad, that is contusion, abrasion and punctate laceration indicates a secondary blast injury.
  • Blast Injury: Blast injuries are complex physical traumas resulting from direct or indirect exposure to an explosion, leading to sudden changes in atmospheric pressure.

[1]

Classification of Blast Injuries

Type

Mechanism

Features

Primary Injury

It results from blast waves and is often internal with no external signs.
  • Ears: Tympanic membrane rupture or inner ear disruption.
  • Lungs: Alveolar-capillary membrane haemorrhage (blast lung), most common cause cause of death in survivors.
  • GIT: Injuries to gas-filled organs are more common in underwater blasts.

Secondary Injury

It is resulting from shrapnel, debris & flying objects (propelled by explosion).
  • Penetrating trauma.
  • The characteristic Marshall triad, which includes bruises, abrasions, and punctate lacerations, is evident.
  • Commonly cause severe thoracic injuries, including lacerations of the heart and great vessels.

Tertiary Injury

Victims are thrown against solid objects by blast winds.
  • Blunt/Penetrating trauma.
  • Includes bone fractures and coup-contrecoup injuries.

Quaternary Injury

Encompass all other injuries not classified above
  • Flash burns from extreme heat.
  • Crush injuries and falls due to explosions.
  • Respiratory injuries from toxic dust, gases, or radiation exposure.
  • Psychiatric issues, such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), may affect individuals even if they are physically unharmed.


Firearm injury (Option A) Presents with entry/exit wounds, possible burns or tattooing (based on the type of injury). Lacerations and contusions may occur, but not all three components consistently.

Road Traffic Accident (RTA) (Option C): Abrasions, contusions, and lacerations can occur, but patterned injuries, fractures, and internal organ damage are more prominent. The triad might be possible, but not common, diagnostic or specific.

﻿﻿﻿Strangulation (Option D) It is characteriwed by ligature marks, petechiae, facial congestion, and neck muscle hemorrhage. Abrasions may be present around the neck, but the full triad is not typical.

FM080

questions.text: A dead body was found with a wound on the neck, with clean-cut edges, crushed tissues along with the disruption of the vertebral bones.Identify the type of wound.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chop wound

Explanation:

A chop wound is characterized by:

  • Clean-cut edges (sharp weapon component).
  • Crushed tissues (blunt force component).
  • Disruption of vertebral bones (high-impact force).

Mechanism:

  • Caused by heavy, sharp-edged weapons like an axe, machete, or cleaver.
  • Combines both incised (clean edges) and lacerated (crushing) features due to the weight and force involved.

Incised wound (Option A): Clean-cut edges without tissue crushing or bone injury.

Lacerated wound (Option C): Irregular edges with tissue bridging, caused by blunt trauma.

Avulsion (Option D): Tearing away of tissue, often from high-velocity trauma or accidents.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with an injury sustained during a football match after being tackled by an opponent. As the casualty medical officer, how would you describe the wound in the case sheet?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Laceration

Explanation:

The above image and scenario are suggestive of a laceration

  • Laceration is the tearing or splitting of the skin, mucous membranes, muscles, or internal organs due to a shearing or crushing force from a blunt impact over a broad area.
  • When blunt force causes severe bruising and damage to deeper tissues, it is referred to as a crush injury.

Characteristics

  • Irregular Margins: Ragged, uneven edges with pointed or blunt ends, often showing small tears.
  • Swallow Tails: Tearing at the ends of lacerations, diverging.
  • Bruising: Seen around the wound, more pronounced in areas impacted at an angle or with downward force.
  • Tissue Bridges: Deeper tissues are unevenly torn, leaving nerve, vessel, and connective tissue bridges.
  • Hair Damage: Crushed hair bulbs; hair and skin tags may be embedded in the wound.
  • Hemorrhage: Less severe bleeding as arteries are crushed and torn irregularly, retracting and allowing blood to clot.
  • Soiling: Debris like mud, wood splinters, sand, glass, or hair can become embedded, carrying medico-legal significance.
  • Wound Gaping: Impact from an angle causes tearing on the opposite side and abrasion on the impact side, leading to gaping.

Incorrect Options:

Incised wounds (Option A): They have clean, smooth edges and do not show the uneven tearing or bruising present in this case.

Abrasions (Option B): They involve superficial skin damage and typically lack deep tissue involvement and significant bruising.

Bruise (Option D): A bruise (contusion) is caused by blunt trauma, leading to subcutaneous bleeding without a break in the skin.

questions.text: A middle-aged man was brought to the ER after an assault with a sharp axe. Identify the type of wound.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chop wound

Explanation:

  • The injury from the scenario is suggestive of a chop wound.
  • A chop wound is a deep injury caused by a heavy, sharp object like an axe.
  • It combines features of both an incised wound (sharp edges) and a lacerated wound (underlying tissue damage and crushing effect).

Chop wounds/ Slash wounds

  • These are deep gaping wounds inflicted by a blow with the moderately sharp cutting edge of a heavy weapon when applied with significant force.
  • It is a combination of blunt and sharp force injury.

Weapons used

  • Hatchet
  • Axe
  • Sword
  • Broad heavy knife
  • Chopper
  • Saber
  • Meat cleaver

Features of the wound
  • The axe's lower end (heel) strikes first, leaving a deeper wound than the upper end (toe).
  • It is an incised wound on skin with an underlying communited fracture or deep grove in the bone.
  • Dimensions of the wound correspond to the cross-section of the penetrating blade.
  • Margins are sharp and may have abrasions, bruising, and some lacerations with severe injury to underlying organs.

Medicolegal importance

  • Most injuries are homicidal.
  • Frew are accidental by machinery (propeller injuries).
  • Rarely suicidal.
  • Wounds give details of the weapon used and the direction of attack.

 

Chop wound on forehead from a propeller accident


Incorrect Options:

Incised wound (Option A): An incised wound is caused by a sharp-edged object, such as a knife or blade, and is characterized by clean-cut edges.

Lacerated wound (Option C): Lacerated wounds are caused by blunt force trauma, resulting in irregular edges. An axe typically causes more defined sharp edges, making it a chop wound rather than a laceration.

Abrasion (Option D): Abrasions are superficial injuries caused by friction or scraping against a rough surface, which is not applicable in the case of an axe assault.

questions.text: A man was working in a field and he suddenly collapsed on a hot summer afternoon. On examination, there were no physical signs of dehydration. His serum electrolyte level was normal. The doctor found that the body temperature was 106 degrees Fahrenheit. Which of the following symptoms is least likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sweating

  • In the given scenario, with a body temperature of 106 degrees Fahrenheit, the symptom that is least likely to be seen in this patient is sweating.
  • Heatstroke is a severe form of heat-related illness characterized by elevated body temperature.
  • Sweating is absent in heat stroke but present in exertional heat stroke

Condition

Cause

Clinical Features

Postmortem Findings

Heat Stroke

 

 

Failure of thermoregulation in extreme heat exposure
  • Sudden collapse-loss of consciousness, due to hypotension (Option B)
  • Skin hot, initially wet, then dry (Option A)
  • Hyperventilation- tachycardia
  • Core temp > 40.5°C/104 F
  • Pupils contracted
  • Convulsions
  • Unconsciousness
  • Cerebral dysfunction (Option D)
  • High fever
  • Absence of sweating (Option C)
  • Congested lungs, intrathoracic petechiae (children)
  • Subendocardial hemorrhages
  • Brain congestion, flattened convolutions, petechiae in the 3rd/4th ventricle walls

questions.text: Identify the lesion shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Incised looking laceration

  • The most appropriate identification for the lesion shown in the image would be Incised-looking laceration.
  • Split lacerations are commonly seen in areas where the skin is close to bone, such as the scalp, with minimal underlying soft tissue. Although the edges may appear sharp, the presence of tissue bridges confirms the diagnosis of a laceration rather than an incised wound.

Types of Laceration

  • Split laceration
  • Avulsion laceration
  • Stretch laceration
  • Tear laceration
  • Cut laceration

Types of Laceration

 

Split Laceration (Incised looking laceration)
  • These occur when skin is crushed between two objects, such as the scalp being compressed between the skull and a hard surface like the ground or a blunt object.
  • Seen on areas where the skin is close to bone, with minimal underlying tissue
  • E.g., scalp, eyebrows, cheekbones, jaw, iliac crest, perineum, shin.
  • Lacerations without excessive skin crushing can have sharp edges, resembling incised wounds.
  • Also known as incised looking laceration.
  • These are not undermined and show tissue bridges.

Avulsion (Shearing Laceration)

 
  • Caused by a shearing force at an acute angle, detaching skin or organs from their attachments.
  • The shearing and grinding force from a heavy object, like a lorry wheel passing over a limb, can cause the skin to separate from the underlying tissues, a condition known as avulsion or "flaying."
  • This often results in crushed muscles and fractured bones. The detached skin may have extensive abrasions due to the tyre’s friction, but one portion is still in continuity with adjacent skin.
  • Lacerations from shearing forces can leave the skin intact while separating the underlying soft tissue from the fascia, resulting in a blood-filled pocket. This type of injury is often observed on the back of the thighs in pedestrians hit by motor vehicles.

Laceration (Option A) is a type of wound that is typically irregular, with jagged or torn edges. It is caused by blunt force trauma or tearing of the skin and underlying tissues.

Incised wound (Option B) is a type of wound that is caused by a sharp object or instrument, resulting in clean, straight edges. In the given image, the wound does not have the characteristic clean and straight edges of an incise wound.

Laceration-looking incised wound (Option C)This option suggests that the wound appears like a laceration but actually has the characteristics of an incised wound. In the given image, the wound does not exhibit the typical features of an incised wound, such as clean and straight edges.

questions.text: Name the type of skull fracture.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hinge fracture

 

Explanation:

The type of skull fracture shown in the image is Hinge fracture. A Hinge fracture involves a break in the skull that allows part of the skull to rotate or pivot around a point, resembling a hinge. This type of fracture typically occurs due to a localized impact or force, often affecting the base or side of the skull.

Motorcyclist Fracture (Hinge Fracture)

(Option B)

Ring Fracture

(Option D ruled out)
  • Transverse fracture at the skull base, splitting it and creating a "hinge" - nodding face sign.
  • It extends from one petrous ridge across the sella turcica to the other petrous ridge.
  • Encircles the foramen magnum at the skull base.
  • Runs from the sella turcica to the petrous ridges and posterior fossa.
  • It can extend to the middle ear and roof of the nose.

Often caused by side impacts.


 

Caused by:

  • Falls landing on feet/buttocks (force transmitted through the spine).
  • Heavy blows to the top of the skull/ vertex.
  • Twisting of the head on the spine.
  • Blows to the occiput or chin.

Hinge fracture

Ring fracture

 

Depressed Fracture (Option A ruled out)
  • Occurs when a fragment of the skull is pushed inward towards the brain.
  • Caused by blows from heavy objects with a small surface (e.g., hammers, bricks).
  • The shape of the depressed area may resemble the object that caused the injury.

Variants:

  • Elevated Fracture: One end of the fractured fragment is raised above the skull, while the other is pushed inward. Caused by sharp objects like an axe.
  • Pond Fracture: Seen in infants, this smooth depression occurs without a fracture line, resembling a dent in a ping-pong ball. Caused by obstetrics forceps blade.(Option C ruled out)

Depressed fracture

questions.text: Identify the injury the image below :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Abrasion

 

Explanation:

Abrasion:

Abrasion is a superficial injury caused by the removal or damage of the skin's outer layer (epidermis) due to friction or pressure. It is classified into four main types:

Scratch Abrasion (Linear Abrasion)

Grazed Abrasion (Sliding Abrasion)

Mechanism: Caused by tangential (side-to-side) force, producing a long and narrow abrasion.

Features: Linear in nature, with length being more significant than width.

Examples: Fingernail abrasion, thorn abrasion, and pin abrasion.


 

Mechanism: Occurs when skin slides over a rough surface, resulting in superficial scrapes.

Also Known As: Grinding abrasion, gravel rash, brush-burn.

Features: Seen in road traffic accidents or falls, especially on exposed areas like knees or elbows.

Imprint Abrasion (Patterned Abrasion)

Pressure Abrasion (Crushing Abrasion)

Mechanism: Results from compressive force applied perpendicular to the skin, leaving a distinct pattern of the object.

Also Known As Impact abrasion, contact abrasion, patterned abrasion.

Examples: Tyre marks, bite marks

 

Mechanism: Caused by a continuous vertical force applied to the skin, crushing the epidermis.

Features: Deeper skin injuries are often seen with prolonged pressure, potentially leading to necrosis.

Examples: Ligature marks in hanging or strangulation

 

Direction of Force in Abrasion

The direction of force applied in an abrasion can be identified based on specific characteristics of the skin damage. At the end of an abrasion, the skin shows distinct features that help determine the direction of the force, particularly through epithelial tags or aggregated lines.

Characteristics of the end of an abrasion:

 

Multiple Lines
  • Indicate the endpoint of the abrasion.
  • Reflect the direction of the applied force.

Uneven and Longitudinal Lines
  • Show irregularity at the end of the abrasion.
  • Suggest pulling or scraping of the skin.

Heaped-up or Aggregated Lines
  • Also known as Epithelial tags (Terminal tags)
  • Skin tissues dragged opposite to the force direction.
  • Point toward the end of the abrasion, indicating the force direction
  • (e.g., tags heaped at the right end, if the force was left to right).

questions.text: A person got stabbed in his anterior thigh and died. His body was brought for postmortem. What type of injury is this?
questions.solution:
A penetrating wound is caused by a sharp object (e.g., a knife) that pierces the skin and enters deeper tissues or body cavities. In this case, the stab wound to the anterior thigh involves a sharp object penetrating the skin and underlying tissues, making it a penetrating wound.


 

Stab wound/Punctured wound

These are inflicted by penetration with long, narrow instruments having pointed (sometimes blunt) ends into the depth of the body, which is deeper than its length and width.

Weapons used

  • Knife (most common)
  • Pieces of glass (broken glass bottle)
  • Scissors
  • Screwdrivers
  • Pens
  • Ice picks
  • Forks

Types of stab wounds

  • Puncture wound: (Option C)
    • Soft tissues are involved
  • Penetrating wound:
    • Enters a body cavity or a viscus
  • Perforating wound:
    • Through-and-through puncture wounds
    • The weapon enters the body from one side and comes out the other
    • The wound of entry is larger than the exit

Significance of the wound dimensions

  • Length is slightly less than the width of the weapon due to the stretching of the skin.
  • Breadth is more than the thickness of weapon due to gaping.
  • Depth, the greatest dimension of the wound, corresponds to the length of the weapon's blade, which has completely entered the body without perforation.
  • Margins or edges of the wound are clean cut with usually no abrasion or bruising.
    • Margins by a pointed or conical weapon have lacerated edges
    • If the hilt guard of the weapon strikes the skin, a regular, sharp, and well-defined patterned abrasion or bruising is formed

Incised wound (Option A): An incised wound is a clean cut caused by a sharp object (e.g., a razor or knife) and is typically longer than it is deep. A stab wound is deeper than it is long, so it does not qualify as an incised wound.

 

Blunt force injury (Option D): This involves trauma caused by a blunt object (e.g., a bat or hammer) and does not involve penetration of the skin or tissues. A stab wound is caused by a sharp object, not blunt force.

questions.text: Post-mortem examination reveals specific findings. What is this finding known as?
questions.solution:
he presence of small, superficial cuts suggests a possible moment of doubt or fear before inflicting the fatal injury. These small cuts can be indicative of hesitation, often observed in scenarios of self-infliction or in cases where the victim may have struggled before the lethal wound.

 

Hesitation cuts:

  • Hesitation cuts (also known as tentative cuts or trial wounds) are multiple, small, superficial cuts that typically involve only the skin.
  • These cuts are often found at the beginning of a deeper incised wound.
  • Psychological Aspect: They suggest that the individual may have hesitated while gathering the courage to make a decisive cut.
  • Forensic Observation: In cases of homicidal sharp force injuries, multiple superficial, roughly parallel incised wounds may appear on the neck, often adjacent to a single deep, lethal incised wound, particularly in instances where torture is involved.


 

Grazed abrasion (Option B):

  • Superficial injury caused by a tangential force, resulting in skin being scraped off.
  • Commonly occurs during falls or friction injuries.

 

Laceration (Option C):

  • Irregular tear in the skin caused by blunt force trauma, often accompanied by tissue bridging.

 

Patterned bruise (Option D):

  • Bruises that replicate the shape of the causative object (e.g., belt marks or shoe prints).
  • Seen in cases of physical assault or trauma.

questions.text: The image provided shows a wound. What type of wound is it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Contusion

 

Explanation

  • A contusion, commonly known as a bruise, results from blunt force trauma causing blood vessels under the skin to rupture.
  • It appears as discoloration of the skin due to subcutaneous bleeding without an open wound. The image likely shows this characteristic discoloration.

 

Abrasion (Option B): An abrasion involves superficial damage to the skin, such as scraping, which removes the epidermis. It does not typically involve subcutaneous bleeding as seen in the image.

 

Laceration (Option C): Lacerations are irregular tears in the skin caused by blunt or sharp trauma. They are characterized by jagged wound edges, which are not visible in the provided image.

 

Stab wound (Option D): A stab wound is caused by a pointed object penetrating the skin. It is characterized by a deep, narrow wound, which is inconsistent with the image.


 

Mechanism of injury of contusions

  • A contusion or bruise is a leak of blood into the tissues due to the rupture of blood vessels (veins, venules, arterioles) caused due to injury by a blunt object.
  • Some blunt objects that can cause contusions are fist, stones, sticks, bar, whip, hammer, axe, wooden handle, poker, foot with shoe or boot, etc.

Factors influencing the formation of bruises

Condition and type of tissues
  • Vascular and loose tissues may form large bruises even with a small degree of violence.
    • Examples: face, vulva, and scrotum.
  • Firm fibrous tissues, strongly supported tissues, and those covered by a thick dermis produce a comparatively small bruise for moderate trauma.
    • Examples: abdomen, back, scalp, palms, and soles.
  • Injury of tissues over bony surfaces shows prominent bruising.

Age

  • Children bruise easily.
  • Older people bruise easily.

Gender

  • Women bruise more easily than men.
  • Obese people bruise easily due to the high volume of subcutaneous tissue.

Colour of the skin

  • Bruising is more easily visible in fair-skinned people than in dark-skinned people.
  • Contusions are better felt in dark-skinned people than seen.

Natural diseases

  • Prominent bruising is seen with minor trauma in patients with:
    • Arteriosclerosis
    • Whooping cough in children due to violent coughing can cause bruising
    • Purpura hemorrhagica
    • Leukemia
    • Hemophilia
    • Scurvy
    • Vitamin K
    • Prothrombin deficiency
    • Phosphorus poisoning
    • Older persons on systemic steroids

Gravity shifting of the blood

  • In deep bruises, blood tracks along the fascial planes and may cause the bruise at a different site.
  • This is called ectopic bruising or percolated or migratory contusion.
  • Examples:
    • Spectacle hematoma or black eye in blunt trauma to the forehead.
    • Bruise behind ear due to basal skull fracture (Battle’s sign).
    • Bruise in the neck from fracture of the jaw.
    • Bruise around the ankle from a kick on the calf.

 

 

 

Learning Objective:

 

Medicolegal importance of bruises:

  • Reexamination after 24 hours is advisable as the bruises appear clearly by this time.
  • Age of injury is determined by color changes.
  • The degree of violence is evaluated by their size.
  • Patterned bruises give details about the object/weapon used.
  • A bruise is grievous when the internal organs are affected.
  • Fabricated bruises are used to falsely accuse someone or in defense of a crime.
  • Postmortem staining should be differentiated from a bruise.
  • Character and manner of injury may be known from the distribution of bruises (six penny bruises from the force of fingertips).

questions.text: Identify the pattern of abrasion shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ligature mark

 

Explanation

 

  • A ligature mark is pressure abrasion caused by the application of a constricting force using a cord-like object (e.g., rope, wire) around the neck.
  • It is commonly observed in cases of hanging or strangulation.
  • Characteristics include a continuous or interrupted band-like mark, which may show the texture or pattern of the ligature material.
  • The location and orientation of the mark can help distinguish hanging from manual strangulation.



 

Pressure abrasion (Option A): Caused by sustained pressure of a blunt object against the skin.

 

Graze abrasion (Option B): Occurs when the skin is scraped against a rough surface.

 

Imprint abrasion (Option D): A patterned abrasion caused when a textured object presses into the skin, leaving a distinct impression.

questions.text: Sequence of rigor mortis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Head to foot:

Rigor mortis, or postmortem rigidity, typically starts in the smaller muscles and progresses to the larger muscle groups. The sequence generally begins with the muscles of the face and neck, followed by the upper limbs, and then extends to the trunk and lower limbs. Therefore, rigor mortis progresses from the head and upper parts of the body downwards towards the feet.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Center to periphery:
Rigor mortis does not progress from the center of the body to the periphery. It starts in the head and moves towards the feet, not the central parts to the outer extremities.

Option C - Foot to head:
Rigor mortis does not start in the feet and move upwards to the head. It starts in the head and progresses downwards towards the feet.

Option D - Simultaneously:
Rigor mortis does not occur simultaneously in all parts of the body. It progresses in a specific sequence, starting with the head and upper body, then moving downwards.

questions.text: What type of fracture is caused by a hammer?
questions.solution:
A hammer is a heavy, blunt object that delivers a focused impact on the skull. This results in a depressed fracture, where the bone is pushed inward at the point of impact, creating a localized depression or indentation.


 

Depressed Fracture

Comminuted Fracture

Gutter Fracture
  • Occurs when a fragment of the skull is pushed inward towards the brain.
  • Caused by blows from heavy objects with a small surface (e.g., hammers, bricks).
  • The shape of the depressed area may resemble the object that caused the injury.

Variants:

  • Elevated Fracture: One end of the fractured fragment is raised above the skull, while the other is pushed inward. Caused by sharp objects like an axe.
  • Pond Fracture: Seen in infants, this smooth depression occurs without a fracture line, resembling a dent in a ping-pong ball. Caused by obstetrics forceps blade.
  • Involves multiple intersecting fracture lines, breaking the bone into several fragments.
  • Caused by high-impact trauma (e.g., vehicular accidents, crushing injuries).
  • It may occur alongside other fractures (e.g., fissured or depressed fractures).
  • Spider web-like patterns on an X-ray are characteristic of comminuted fractures.
  • In severe cases, bone fragments may penetrate the brain or become displaced.
  • A groove or channel is formed in the skull bone, often due to an oblique bullet wound.
  • Frequently associated with comminuted and depressed fractures of the inner skull table.
  • Bone fragments can cause injury to the meninges or brain.

 

Depressed fracture

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented with multiple burn injuries involving the entire head, neck & upper limb. What is the percentage of burn?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 25-30%

 

Explanation:

 

In children, the total body surface area (TBSA) percentages differ from adults due to the larger head-to-body ratio. According to the Rule of Nines adjusted for children and the Lund and Browder chart:

  • The entire head and neck account for approximately 18% of the TBSA in a 3-year-old child.

  • Each upper limb accounts for approximately 9% of the TBSA.

Adding these together:
18% (head and neck) + 9% (one upper limb) = 27%

 

According to the Wallace rule of 9, this is how the area burned is calculated:

40-44% (Option B): This value overestimates the burn area. A 40-44% burn would imply involvement of larger or additional body areas beyond the head, neck, and one upper limb, such as parts of the trunk or both upper limbs.

18-20% (Option C): This value roughly corresponds to the head and neck alone, without including the upper limb. Since the upper limb is also involved, the percentage should be higher.

5-10% (Option D): This severely underestimates the burn size. The entire head and neck alone exceed 10%, so including one upper limb must be substantially more.

questions.text: Identify the bullet range
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Close range:

When a gunshot wound shows blackening and tattooing around it, this indicates a close-range shot. Blackening is caused by the deposition of soot and gunpowder residue from the burning propellant, while tattooing is due to the impact of unburned powder particles. These signs are typically seen when the muzzle is relatively close to the target, usually within a few feet.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Distant range:

At a distant range, the wound would not exhibit blackening or tattooing because the gunpowder residues would not have had a chance to settle on the skin. Distant range wounds usually present with a clean entry wound without additional residues.

Option B - Close contact:

Close contact wounds are typically characterized by a much more severe pattern, such as a star-shaped wound with burning and possibly charring of the skin. The presence of blackening and tattooing suggests a somewhat less extreme range, but still close.

Option D - Cannot be predicted:

The presence of blackening and tattooing can indeed predict the bullet range with a reasonable degree of certainty. Therefore, this option is not accurate as the gunshot range can be estimated based on these features.

questions.text: During measurement of a rifled barrel weapon, the caliber depends on?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Distance between two opposite lands

Explanation:

  • In forensic ballistics, "caliber" refers to the diameter of a rifled firearm's barrel, specifically measured between opposing lands. This measurement, typically expressed in inches or millimetres, is crucial for linking a bullet to a specific firearm.

Rifled Firearms:

  • Rifled firearms have a bore characterised by a series of grooves that spiral along the barrel's length. These grooves (Option B), known as "rifling," alternate with raised areas called "lands." The caliber is determined by measuring the distance between these lands. (Option A)
  • The direction of rifling can be either right (clockwise) or left (counter-clockwise), with most handguns featuring a right-hand twist.
  • As the bullet travels through the barrel, it engages with the lands and grooves, imparting a spin that stabilises its flight and leaves distinctive markings on the bullet, which serve as identifiers for the firearm.

Number of lead pellets (Option C)

  • Bore or Gauge: It is used for smooth bore weapons. The number of balls/pellets of equal size/weight made from 1 pound lead (454g) 12 bore = 12 balls

Mass and velocity (Option D) of a projectile fired from a rifled barrel weapon are important factors in its performance, they are not used directly to determine the caliber of the weapon

questions.text: The most common organ injuries in air blast shock waves will be?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Lungs

Explanation:

  • The most common organ injured in an air blast shock wave is the tympanic membrane (TM); given that the options do not contain TM, the next best answer is the lung.
  • Blast lung is a primary blast injury. The shock wave causes immediate lung injury, characterized by the rupture of alveolar capillaries.

Blast Injury:

Extent of Damage

  • Greater damage compared to bullet injuries due to complex blast waves.
  • Explosion pressure wave exceeds 1000 pounds per square inch, involving incident and reflected pressure.

Factors Causing Damage

  • High-pressure wave impact.
  • Mechanical, chemical, and thermal injuries.
  • Inhalation of toxic gases and smoke.

Types of blast injuries:

 

Air Blast Injuries

Underwater Blast Injuries

Most commonly injured:

Tympanic membrane (ear) - Rupture and middle ear damage are common
  • Tympanic membrane (ear) - More likely to occur when the head is submerged.
  • Gastrointestinal tract - When the head is not submerged.

Most severely injured:

Lungs - Blast lung injury is a common cause of delayed mortality and can cause pulmonary contusion, air embolism, and other damage

Gastrointestinal tract - Underwater blasts can cause more severe GI injuries due to pressure effects on hollow organs


Intestine, kidney, and heart (Options A, C, and D) are not the most common injuries in air blast

questions.text: During a forensic autopsy, a gunshot victim is examined, and the doctor observes that the firearm injury has a stellate shape. What will be the range of gunshot?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Contact shot

  • A contact shot occurs when the muzzle of the firearm is in direct contact with the victim's skin at the time of firing. This results in the deposition of soot, unburned powder particles, and even possible charring around the entrance wound. The gases and particles from the gunpowder can cause the surrounding skin to exhibit a stellate or star-shaped pattern due to the pressure and heat.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Close shot: A close shot refers to a gunshot that is fired from a relatively short distance, usually within a few inches to a few feet. In a close shot, there might be stippling or soot deposition around the entrance wound, but the injury would not typically exhibit a stellate (star-shaped) appearance.

Option C - Near shot: A near shot, also known as a close intermediate shot, refers to a gunshot fired from a short distance but not in direct contact with the skin. The range is usually a few inches to a few feet. This might result in stippling or powder tattooing around the entrance wound due to the impact of unburned gunpowder particles on the skin. However, it is less likely to produce a stellate wound pattern as seen in contact shots.

Option D - Distant shot: A distant shot is fired from a considerable distance, and the effects on the body are determined by the range of fire. At a greater distance, the bullet's energy dissipates, and there may be no stippling or soot deposition around the entrance wound. The wound tends to be cleaner and smaller compared to closer shots. A stellate wound pattern is unlikely to be present in a distant shot.

questions.text: The dead body of a 30-year-old male drowning victim was brought in for autopsy. Upon examination, multiple cuts were observed on the victim's arm. What finding is likely to be seen in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Defense wound

  • When a person is attacked or struggling to defend themselves against an assailant, they might sustain what are known as defense wounds. These wounds typically occur on the flexor surface of the forearm, as individuals instinctively raise their arms to protect their face and body during an attack. The cuts on the victim's arm in this scenario are consistent with defense wounds, suggesting that the victim was trying to shield themselves from harm.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Self-inflicted injury: Self-inflicted injuries are wounds that a person intentionally inflicts upon themselves. These injuries might result from self-harm or suicide attempts. However, in the given scenario, the presence of multiple cuts on the victim's arm does not necessarily suggest self-inflicted injury, as the location and pattern of the cuts seem more indicative of defensive actions rather than self-infliction.

Option C - Accidental cut wound from falling: An accidental cut wound from falling might result from an individual accidentally coming into contact with a sharp object while falling. However, this scenario is less likely in this case because the presence of multiple cuts on the flexor surface of the arm is not consistent with typical patterns of injuries sustained during a fall.

Option D - Washer-women hands: "Washer-women hands" is a term used to describe the appearance of the fingers and hands after prolonged exposure to water, like during laundry work. This option is not relevant to the scenario described, as it does not explain the presence of multiple cuts on the victim's arm or the context of the drowning incident.

questions.text: Which of the following injuries is not expected in a person brought to the hospital with a history of a road traffic accident (RTA)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Chop wound

Explanation:

  • Chop wounds are deep, incised wounds caused by heavy, sharp-edged weapons like axes or machetes.

Chop/ Slash wound

  • Deep, gaping wounds caused by a blow from a sharp-cutting edge of a heavy weapon (e.g., hatchet, axe, sword, chopper).
  • Wound size corresponds to the cross-section of the blade.
  • Undermining occurs in the direction of chop.
  • The heel (lower end) of the axe typically strikes first, leading to deeper wounds than the toe (upper end).
  • The deeper end indicates the assailant's position.
  • Clean slicing through bone at impact; rebound can create irregular fragments; may lead to complete or incomplete amputations.
  • Mostly homicidal injuries to exposed body parts (head, face, neck, extremities)

Incorrect Options:

Contusion (Option A): Contusions (bruises) are commonly observed in RTAs due to blunt force trauma sustained during the impact or collision.

Abrasions (Option B): Abrasions are also frequent in RTAs, resulting from friction or scraping of the skin against rough surfaces, such as the road or vehicle parts.

Laceration (Option C): Lacerations, or irregular tears in the skin, are often seen in RTAs, especially in cases involving glass shards, sharp edges of vehicles, or other objects.

questions.text: A 42 year old patient, a case of road traffic accident presented with EDH due to involvement of Middle Meningeal Artery. Where will the impact of collision be?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pterion

  • The impact of the collision resulting in an epidural hematoma (EDH) due to involvement of the Middle Meningeal Artery is likely to occur at the pterion. The pterion is a small, delicate area on the side of the skull where four bones come together: the frontal bone, the parietal bone, the temporal bone, and the sphenoid bone. This area is particularly vulnerable to traumatic injury due to its thin bone structure and the presence of the Middle Meningeal Artery, which runs just beneath the skull in this region. Trauma to the pterion can lead to a rupture of the Middle Meningeal Artery, causing bleeding between the dura mater and the skull, resulting in an epidural hematoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Angle of mandible: The angle of the mandible is the outermost point of the lower jawbone. While trauma to this area can cause facial injuries, it is not directly associated with the development of an epidural hematoma due to involvement of the Middle Meningeal Artery.

Option C - Lambdoid suture: The lambdoid suture is the joint between the occipital bone (back of the skull) and the parietal bones. Trauma to this area can result in injuries to the posterior part of the skull, but it is not typically associated with epidural hematomas involving the Middle Meningeal Artery.

Option D - Nasion: The nasion is the intersection point between the frontal bone and the two nasal bones. Trauma to this area can lead to facial injuries, but it is not directly associated with the development of an epidural hematoma due to involvement of the Middle Meningeal Artery.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics is not typically associated with a true bruise?

choices.text: Progression of the color of bruise over time

questions.solution:
Option D. Presence of vesicles:

  • Itching is not typically associated with true bruises. This symptom is more characteristic of artificial bruises caused by substances that irritate the skin.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Negative chemical tests:

  • True bruises usually test negative for the presence of certain chemicals that might be used to create artificial bruises. This is consistent with the definition of a true bruise, which results from the extravasation of blood due to blunt force trauma, not chemical irritation .

Option B. Progression of the color of bruise over time:

  • One of the hallmark characteristics of true bruises is the progression of color changes over time due to the breakdown of hemoglobin in the tissue. This progression typically goes from red or purple to blue, green, yellow, and finally fading away .

.Option C. Irregular margins:

  • True bruises often have irregular, diffuse margins due to the spread of blood within the tissues. This is in contrast to artificial bruises, which typically have well-defined, regular margins due to the application method of the irritant substance .

questions.text: Paradoxical undressing is seen in :
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hypothermia:

  • Paradoxical undressing is a phenomenon commonly observed in cases of severe hypothermia. Hypothermia is a condition characterized by a dangerously low body temperature, usually below 35 degrees Celsius (95 degrees Fahrenheit).
  •  This behavior is thought to result from the disorientation and confusion caused by hypothermia, as well as the dilation of blood vessels near the skin's surface, which can create a false sensation of warmth.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Heart stress: It is not associated with paradoxical undressing.

Option B - Voyeurism: Voyeurism is a paraphilic disorder characterized by an individual's sexual interest and pleasure derived from observing others without their consent. It is unrelated to paradoxical undressing.

Option D - LSD overdose: Overdosing on LSD can cause a variety of physical and psychological effects, but paradoxical undressing is not a known symptom.

questions.text: Identify the injury the image below :
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Abrasion:

  • Based on the image, it is showing an abrasion on the palm. An abrasion is a superficial injury that occurs when the skin is scraped or rubbed against a rough surface, resulting in the removal of the superficial layers of skin. It typically appears as a shallow, irregular-shaped wound with a reddish or pinkish color. 

Incorrect Options:

 Option B - Laceration: A laceration is a type of injury characterized by a deep cut or tear in the skin and underlying tissues. It typically has clean or irregular edges.

Option C - Bruise: A bruise is a discoloration of the skin caused by the rupture of blood vessels beneath the skin surface. It appears as a reddish, purple, or blue mark and is often the result of blunt force trauma ,it does not involve the removal of skin layers.

Option D - Imprint: An imprint refers to a pattern or mark left on the skin as a result of contact with an object or surface.

questions.text: Name the type of skull fracture.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hinge fracture:

  • In the given scenario where the image shows the base of the skull divided in half, the specific type of skull fracture is known as a "hinge fracture." A hinge fracture is a specific subtype of basilar skull fracture, which involves a separation or splitting of the base of the skull along a hinge-like mechanism.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Depressed fracture: A depressed fracture is a type of skull fracture where the bone fragments are depressed or pushed inward. It does not correspond to the given image.

Option C - Pond fracture: Pond fracture is not a recognized term for a specific type of skull fracture.

Option D - Comminuted fracture: Comminuted fracture refers to a fracture in which the bone is fragmented into multiple pieces. It does not correspond to the given image.

questions.text: Bullet fingerprinting involve:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Both:

  • Bullet fingerprinting is a technique used in forensic investigations to analyze the unique markings left on bullets or cartridge cases by the firearm used to discharge them. 

  • Primary markings include the lands and grooves on the inside of the barrel, which leave distinct striations on the bullet or cartridge case as it passes through the barrel. These primary markings are the key elements that make each firearm's tool marks unique.

  • Secondary markings, may be present on a bullet or cartridge case due to factors such as the firing mechanism, extractor, or ejector of the firearm. 

  • When analyzing a bullet or cartridge case, forensic experts examine both the primary and secondary markings to compare them with test-fired bullets or cartridge cases from suspect firearms

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Primary markings: Primary markings alone do not encompass the complete analysis involved in bullet fingerprinting.

Option B - Secondary markings: Secondary markings alone are also not sufficient for bullet fingerprinting analysis.

Option D - None: None is incorrect because bullet fingerprinting does involve the examination of both primary and secondary markings.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about the given condition except:

Incorrect Options:

Option B - It is most commonly caused by incisors and canines: These teeth are more likely to leave identifiable patterns and impressions in a bite mark.

questions.text: What is bullet wipe ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Residual from barrel of gun:

  • Bullet wipe refers to the residue or material that is left behind on a target when a bullet passes through it. This residue is primarily composed of substances such as soot, lubricants, and metal particles that are present in the barrel of the gun. 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Blackening: Blackening typically refers to the darkening or discoloration of a surface due to various factors such as oxidation, charring, or exposure to heat.

Option C - Gutter fracture of the skull: Gutter fracture is a term used to describe a specific type of fracture in the skull, characterized by a groove or channel-like indentation.

Option D - Tattooing: Tattooing, in the context of firearms, refers to the deposition of gunpowder particles or other debris onto the skin when a firearm is discharged at close range.

questions.text: In alleged history of gunshot injury, there is burning, blackening, tattooing around the wound. The injury is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Close shot entry wound:

  • When a gunshot injury occurs at close range, the muzzle of the firearm is in close proximity to the body. In such cases, the burning, blackening, and tattooing of the skin around the wound are commonly observed. These characteristics are due to the presence of unburned gunpowder particles and hot gasses discharged from the firearm.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Close shot exit wound: In close shot exit wounds, the burning, blackening, and tattooing effects are usually not present. Close shot exit wounds are characterized by an irregular or stellate appearance, as the bullet exits the body and causes tissue disruption.

Option C - Distant shot entry wound: In distant shot entry wounds, there is a significant distance between the muzzle of the firearm and the body. The effects of burning, blackening, and tattooing are not typically observed in such cases. Distant shot entry wounds may appear as small, circular or oval-shaped holes without the characteristics associated with close-range shots.

Option D - Distant shot exit wound: Similar to distant shot entry wounds, distant shot exit wounds do not exhibit the effects of burning, blackening, and tattooing. These exit wounds are often characterized by a smaller size compared to close shot exit wounds.

questions.text: During the examination of injury, hair bulbs are noted to be crushed. The probable type of wound is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Laceration:

  • Laceration involves the tearing or cutting of tissues, which can crush the underlying hair bulbs.

  • It often results from blunt force trauma, which can cause compression and crushing of the hair bulbs.

  • Crushed hair bulbs indicate a significant force applied to the area, consistent with a laceration.

Characteristics of Lacerations:

  • Trauma: Blunt trauma, may be heavy

  • Damage: 3-Dimensional injury

  • Margins: Irregular

  • Floor: Vessels, nerve, and hair bulb are crushed.

  • Structures: Epidermis +dermis + subcutaneous tissue.

  • Swallow tail, tearing at the end, diverging.

  • Tissue bridges and tissue fragments connect each other from the margin.

  • Bleeding comparatively due to crushed blood vessels.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Abrasions: Abrasions typically involve superficial damage to the skin without significant underlying tissue injury. They do not usually cause crushing of hair bulbs.

Option C - Stab injuries: Stab injuries are caused by a pointed object piercing the skin. While they may cause damage to the underlying tissues, they do not typically result in crushed hair bulbs.

Option D - None: This option is incorrect because the description in the question indicates a specific type of wound characterized by crushed hair bulbs corresponding to a laceration.

questions.text: During the examination of a victim of assault, you notice a wound with ragged, irregular and uneven margins with tears diverging at an angle from the end of the main wound and typical swallowtails. Bleeding from this wound is not significant and shows crushed blood vessels and hair bulbs. You would document this wound as a/an.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Lacerated wound:

  • The wound described in the scenario is most likely a lacerated wound due to its ragged, irregular, and uneven margins with tears diverging at an angle from the end of the main wound and typical ‘swallowtails’.

  • Bleeding from this wound is not significant and shows crushed blood vessels and hair bulbs.

  • Lacerated wounds are typically caused by blunt force trauma and have an irregular shape with jagged margins. They can also be caused by tearing, such as in cases of dog bites or machinery accidents. Therefore, the wound should be documented as a lacerated wound.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Incised wound: An incised wound typically has clean and sharp margins and is caused by a sharp-edged instrument like a knife. The edges of an incised wound are not ragged, irregular, or uneven, and there are no tears diverging at an angle from the end of the main wound or "swallow tails."

Option B - Chopped wound: A chopped wound is a type of wound caused by a heavy, sharp-edged object, such as an axe or a machete. It typically has a clean, straight edge with minimal tissue damage. 

Option C - Stab wound: A stab wound typically has a narrow and deep wound track with straight or slightly curved margins, and a clean and smooth wound surface. It is caused by a pointed object such as a knife, dagger, or ice pick penetrating the skin and underlying tissues.
